quizQuestions.questionText: How many conditions must an act of worship meet to be in accordance with Shari'ah?

options.text: Six conditions: reason, type, amount, manner, time, and place
Four conditions: reason, type, amount, and manner
Five conditions: type, amount, manner, time, and place
Three conditions: reason, manner, and time

quizQuestions.explanation: According to Shaykh Muhammad ibn Salih ibn 'Uthaymin, an act of worship must be in accordance with Shari'ah in six aspects: (1) reason, (2) type or nature, (3) amount, (4) manner of doing it, (5) timing, and (6) place where it is done.

quizQuestions.questionText: What example does the scholar give of worship that violates Shari'ah in terms of the type or nature of the action?

options.text: Sacrificing a horse instead of an animal from the an'am class (camel, cow, or sheep)
Praying Zuhr as six rak'ahs instead of four
Doing wudu by washing feet before wiping the head
Fasting Ramadan in Sha'ban or Shawwal

quizQuestions.explanation: The answer specifically states that sacrificing a horse would be contrary to Shari'ah in the nature of the action, because a sacrifice can only involve an animal of the an'am class, namely a camel, a cow or a sheep.

quizQuestions.questionText: What is the ruling on clenching fingers to count rak'ahs during prayer according to Shaykh Ibn Baaz?

options.text: There is nothing wrong with it; it is a small movement in the interests of the prayer
It is makrooh because it involves unnecessary movement during prayer
It invalidates the prayer because it is too much movement
It is only allowed in voluntary prayers, not obligatory ones

quizQuestions.explanation: Shaykh 'Abd al-'Azeez ibn Baaz stated that there is nothing wrong with clenching one or two fingers so as not to forget. He explained it is a small movement that is in the interests of the prayer, so it is excused.

quizQuestions.questionText: What evidence do scholars cite for the permissibility of appointing someone to take over as imam during prayer?

options.text: When 'Umar was stabbed while praying, he took 'Abd al-Rahman ibn 'Awf's hand and made him lead the remainder of the prayer
The Prophet (peace be upon him) appointed Abu Bakr to take over when he was ill
'Ali ibn Abi Talib appointed his son to complete the prayer when he became sick
Ibn 'Abbas narrated that the Prophet allowed changing imams mid-prayer

quizQuestions.explanation: The answer specifically mentions that when 'Umar ibn al-Khattab was stabbed as he was praying, he took the hand of 'Abd al-Rahman ibn 'Awf and made him move forward to lead the people in the remainder of the prayer. This was done in the presence of the Sahabah with no objection, establishing consensus.

quizQuestions.questionText: When an imam is overcome with weeping during prayer, what should he do if he has already finished reciting al-Fatihah?

options.text: He may stop reciting and bow, as reciting after al-Fatihah is not obligatory
He must appoint someone else to complete the prayer with the congregation
He should continue reciting even with difficulty to avoid breaking the prayer
He should invalidate the prayer and restart after regaining composure

quizQuestions.explanation: The answer states that if the imam has finished reciting al-Fatihah and is then overcome with weeping while reciting Qur'an after al-Fatihah, he may stop reciting and bow, and does not have to do anything else. This is because reciting something else in addition to al-Fatihah is not obligatory.

quizQuestions.questionText: What does Shaykh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyah say about the prostration of all created beings?

options.text: Everything prostrates according to its nature, not by putting foreheads on the ground
All creatures prostrate exactly like humans do, on seven parts of the body
Prostration of non-human creatures is metaphorical, not real prostration
Only living creatures prostrate; inanimate objects do not truly prostrate

quizQuestions.explanation: Ibn Taymiyah stated: 'It is known that everything prostrates according to its nature, and the prostration of these created entities does not mean that they put their foreheads on the ground.' He explained that prostration is a form of humility, and each creature prostrates in a manner appropriate to it.

quizQuestions.questionText: If a man and woman hold hands and kiss after the marriage contract but before consummation, what is the ruling?

options.text: There is no sin, because by the marriage contract the woman becomes the wife of the man
It is haram and they must repent and offer expiation
It is makrooh but not sinful since they are engaged
It is only permissible if they have parental permission

quizQuestions.explanation: The answer clearly states: 'If this is what is referred to in the question, then there is no sin on you for what happened between you, because simply by doing the marriage contract, the woman becomes the wife of the man and there is no sin on either of them for enjoying the other.'

quizQuestions.questionText: What did the Prophet (peace be upon him) prescribe to do after the burial of the deceased is finished?

options.text: Stand at the graveside and say: 'Pray for forgiveness for your brother and ask for him to be made steadfast, for now he is being questioned'
Recite 'Laa ilaaha ill-Allah, al-daayim wajh-Allah' audibly
Say 'Yaa Rahmaan, yaa Rahmaan' at the time of burial
Remain silent and ponder one's own fate without speaking

quizQuestions.explanation: According to Shaykh Ibn 'Uthaymeen, when the burial of the deceased was finished, the Prophet would stand at the graveside and say: 'Pray for forgiveness for your brother and ask for him to be made steadfast, for now he is being questioned.' This is what is prescribed in Islam.

quizQuestions.questionText: What conditions do scholars require for using poison or venom for medicinal purposes?

options.text: It must be prescribed by a skilled doctor, proven to be beneficial, used safely, and have no alternative treatment available
It is only allowed in life-threatening emergencies with no other options
It requires approval from three doctors and must be diluted to 10% concentration
It can be used freely as long as the patient gives informed consent

quizQuestions.explanation: Al-Mawsu'ah al-Fiqhiyyah states it is permissible 'provided that it can be used in a safe way and there is the hope that it will be beneficial, by way of choosing the less harmful of two options and warding off the greater harm, on condition that you seek the advice of a Muslim doctor of good character, or you have good knowledge of what can be used for medicinal purposes, and there is no alternative that could treat the problem.'

quizQuestions.questionText: What historical evidence does the answer provide about the origin of vaccination?

options.text: Inoculation was known to Muslims before others and brought to Europe from Turkey by the wife of the English ambassador in 1724 CE
Edward Jenner learned vaccination techniques from Islamic scholars in Egypt
The Prophet (peace be upon him) practiced a form of vaccination using natural herbs
Muslim doctors in Andalusia developed the first vaccines in the 12th century

quizQuestions.explanation: The answer cites Paul Vallely's article stating: 'The technique of inoculation was not invented by Jenner and Pasteur but was devised in the Muslim world and brought to Europe from Turkey by the wife of the English ambassador to Istanbul in 1724 CE.'

quizQuestions.questionText: For whom is ghusl on the day of 'Arafah prescribed according to the scholars?

options.text: Only for pilgrims performing Hajj, as it is bathing for gathering with people in 'Arafah
For all Muslims worldwide, whether performing Hajj or not
Only for those in Makkah and the surrounding areas
For pilgrims and Muslims who fast on the day of 'Arafah

quizQuestions.explanation: The answer clarifies: 'It should be understood that doing ghusl for the day of 'Arafah is not for every Muslim; rather it is only for the pilgrim, because this is what is narrated from the Sahabah (may Allah be pleased with them), and because it is bathing for the purpose of gathering with people, and the gathering only takes place in 'Arafah.'

quizQuestions.questionText: Which Sahabah are specifically mentioned as having done ghusl on the day of 'Arafah?

options.text: Ibn Mas'ood, Ibn 'Umar, and 'Ali (may Allah be pleased with them)
Abu Bakr, 'Umar, and 'Uthman (may Allah be pleased with them)
Abu Hurayrah, Ibn 'Abbas, and Mu'adh (may Allah be pleased with them)
Bilal, Salman, and Abu Dharr (may Allah be pleased with them)

quizQuestions.explanation: The answer states: 'It is proven from more than one of the Sahaabah that they did ghusl for the day of 'Arafah â€“ such as Ibn Mas'ood, Ibn 'Umar and 'Ali (may Allah be pleased with them).'

quizQuestions.questionText: What examples does the answer give of cooperating in sin and transgression?

options.text: Renting stores to riba-based banks, helping manufacture haraam products, or enabling followers of bid'ah to speak to Muslims
Teaching English to someone with incorrect beliefs, working for non-Muslim employers, or selling permissible goods
Lending money without interest, selling food to non-Muslims, or teaching general knowledge
Working in technology, teaching languages, or providing professional services

quizQuestions.explanation: The answer specifically states: 'Examples of cooperating in sin and transgression include: renting out stores to riba-based banks or stores that sell haraam things, joining a businessman in manufacturing, selling or buying haraam things, or helping followers of bid'ah (innovation) financially or by enabling them to speak to the Muslims, and so on.'

quizQuestions.questionText: What did Shaykh Ibn 'Uthaymin say about a woman who has applied henna to her hands or feet?

options.text: She must cover them whether she has applied henna or not when non-mahram men are around
She may show her hands but must cover her feet at all times
She only needs to cover henna if it is brightly colored or decorative
She may show henna to elderly non-mahram men but not young ones

quizQuestions.explanation: Shaykh Ibn 'Uthaymin stated: 'she must cover her hands, although covering the hands is what is prescribed for a woman if there are non-mahram men around her, whether she has applies henna to them or not.' This emphasizes that covering is required regardless of henna.
